title: 2014–15 Pro12
text:
The 2014–15 Pro12 (also known as the "Guinness Pro12" for sponsorship reasons) was the 14th season of the professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> competition originally known as the <a href="Pro14">Celtic League</a>, and the fifth with its current four-country format.
It was the first season to be referred to as the "Pro12" to not have <a href="Rabobank">RaboDirect</a> as the title sponsor, having been replaced by <a href="Guinness%20Brewery">Guinness</a>.
<a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> were the defending champions having beaten <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> in the previous season's <a href="2014%20Pro12%20Grand%20Final">playoff final</a>, to become the first team in the league to successfully retain the trophy. Leinster were unable to defend their title as they failed to qualify for the end-of-season playoffs for the top four teams after the regular season. Glasgow Warriors finished the regular season on top of the table, and were crowned champions for the first time, beating second seeded team <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a> 31–13 in the final. Thus, the Warriors became the first Scottish team to win a professional trophy, beating <a href="Edinburgh%20Rugby">Edinburgh</a>'s appearance in the final of the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20European%20Rugby%20Challenge%20Cup">2014–15 European Rugby Challenge Cup</a>.
The twelve competing teams were the four Irish teams, <a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a>, Leinster, Munster and <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a>; two Italian teams, <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a> and <a href="Zebre">Zebre</a>; two Scottish teams, Edinburgh and Glasgow Warriors and four Welsh teams, <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a>, <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a>, <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> and <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>.
The Guinness PRO12 Trophy is a 60 cm tall piece handmade made by silversmith <a href="Thomas%20Lyte">Thomas Lyte</a> from 8.3 kg of sterling silver, with league branding highlighted in gold plate.
Changes for the season.
All countries.
With the <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> being replaced by the 20-team <a href="European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup">European Rugby Champions Cup</a> in the 2014–15 season, the Pro12 table had a greater impact on qualification. Though the qualification was decided by the league table in the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Pro12">2013–14 season</a>, teams were not aware this would be the case until April 2014.
Under the previous format, the Pro12 provided a minimum of ten teams, with Scotland and Italy providing two teams each, and Ireland and Wales both providing three. The new system saw one place now being reserved for the highest finishing Pro12 team from each of four participating countries and three other qualifiers based solely on league position, for a total of seven teams. The other teams were entered in the new second-tier competition, the <a href="European%20Rugby%20Challenge%20Cup">European Rugby Challenge Cup</a>.
Starting in the 2015–16 competition, the 20th tournament spot will be decided by a playoff involving the Pro12's highest-finishing team that has not already qualified, the seventh highest finishing club from France's <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> and the seventh highest finishing club from the <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">English Premiership</a>. The play-off was initially planned to involve two Pro12 teams, but that plan was scrapped due to fixture clashes with the Top 14.
Ireland.
<a href="Connacht%20Rugby">Connacht</a> entered the season with a new captain following the forced retirement of <a href="Craig%20Clarke">Craig Clarke</a> due to persistent concussions. <a href="John%20Muldoon%20%28rugby%20player%20born%201982%29">John Muldoon</a> was confirmed as the new captain in August 2014. They were also without the playing services of former captain and centurion <a href="Gavin%20Duffy%20%28sportsman%29">Gavin Duffy</a>, whose contract was not renewed the previous season. It was later announced that he had taken up a role with the province's commercial team.
<a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> came into the competition without the services of long serving player <a href="Brian%20O%27Driscoll">Brian O'Driscoll</a>, who retired at the end of the 2013–14 season, for the first time. O'Driscoll had played in every previous season of the league. They were also without last year's captain <a href="Leo%20Cullen%20%28rugby%20union%29">Leo Cullen</a> on the playing field, as he also retired, taking up the role of forwards coach. Irish international <a href="Jamie%20Heaslip">Jamie Heaslip</a> was announced as the side's new captain in August 2014, with <a href="Rob%20Kearney">Rob Kearney</a> and <a href="Se%C3%A1n%20O%27Brien%20%28rugby%20union%2C%20born%201987%29">Seán O'Brien</a> serving as his vice-captains.
Following the departure of last year's head coach <a href="Rob%20Penney">Rob Penney</a>, who took up a role with the Japanese side <a href="NTT%20Communications%20Shining%20Arcs">NTT Communications Shining Arcs</a>, <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a> were coached by former player and previous season's forwards coach <a href="Anthony%20Foley">Anthony Foley</a>. Foley was joined in the coaching staff by his fellow former Munster players <a href="Mick%20O%27Driscoll">Mick O'Driscoll</a> and <a href="Jerry%20Flannery">Jerry Flannery</a>, as well as <a href="Cork%20Constitution">Cork Constitution</a> head coach Brian Walsh.
<a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> entered the season with their home stadium, the <a href="Kingspan%20Stadium">Kingspan Stadium</a> redeveloped, with the stadium's capacity having been increased to 18,196. In June 2014, <a href="David%20Humphreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">David Humphreys</a> left his post as the province's Director of Rugby, joining <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">English Premiership</a> side <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a>. Later that month, it was announced that head coach <a href="Mark%20Anscombe">Mark Anscombe</a> would also leave the province "with immediate effect". assistant coach <a href="Les%20Kiss">Les Kiss</a> filled the role of Director of Rugby on an interim basis. In October 2014, Kiss returned to his position with the Ireland team, with <a href="Neil%20Doak">Neil Doak</a> taking the role of head coach. It was announced that Kiss would return to his role with Ulster on a full-time basis following the <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 World Cup</a>. In addition to the changes in the coaching staff, Ulster entered the season with <a href="Rory%20Best">Rory Best</a> reinstated as captain, following the retirement of <a href="Johann%20Muller%20%28rugby%20player%29">Johann Muller</a> at the end of the previous season.
Italy.
Despite threats during the previous season that the team would be pulled out of the competition, <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a> returned for their fifth season in the league. Following the resignation of Franco Smith during the course of the previous season, Umberto Casellato took over as the side's head coach. Casellato joined the side from <a href="Zebre">Zebre</a> where he had served as assistant coach.
Scotland.
Ahead of the 2014–15 season, <a href="Edinburgh%20Rugby">Edinburgh</a> lost a number of experienced players, including <a href="Geoff%20Cross">Geoff Cross</a>, <a href="Nick%20De%20Luca">Nick De Luca</a>, <a href="Greig%20Laidlaw">Greig Laidlaw</a> and <a href="Ross%20Rennie">Ross Rennie</a>. The departure of Laidlaw meant Edinburgh came into the competition with a new captain, and in September 2014, <a href="Mike%20Coman">Mike Coman</a> was named as skipper. Edinburgh's home ground of <a href="Murrayfield%20Stadium">Murrayfield</a> was resurfaced by the time the new season began, following an infestation of <a href="nematode">nematode</a>s, a type of parasitic worm. In addition to being resurfaced, Murrayfield was renamed under a naming rights agreement with the <a href="BT%20Group">BT Group</a>. The deal saw the ground referred to as 'BT Murrayfield Stadium'.
Wales.
Beginning in 2014–15, the <a href="BT%20Group">BT Group</a> became the main sponsor on the shirts of three of the four Welsh teams, sponsoring <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a>, <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> and <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>, while <a href="Cardiff%20Blues">Cardiff Blues</a> had their home stadium of <a href="Cardiff%20Arms%20Park">Cardiff Arms Park</a> renamed under a deal with the group, which saw it referred to officially as 'BT Sport Cardiff Arms Park'.
Cardiff Blues entered the season under new leadership, with <a href="Mark%20Hammett">Mark Hammett</a> coming in as director of rugby. <a href="Dale%20McIntosh">Dale McIntosh</a> and <a href="Paul%20John%20%28rugby%29">Paul John</a> stay on as coaches under him. Hammett joined from <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> franchise, the <a href="Hurricanes%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hurricanes</a>. The Blues were without <a href="Leigh%20Halfpenny">Leigh Halfpenny</a>, whose departure to <a href="RC%20Toulonnais">Toulon</a> was announced in January 2014. captain <a href="Sam%20Warburton">Sam Warburton</a> continued playing with the side as the first centrally contracted player in Wales, having signed a deal with the <a href="Welsh%20Rugby%20Union">Welsh Rugby Union</a> in January 2014. It was also announced that, following his recovery from <a href="testicular%20cancer">testicular cancer</a>, <a href="Matthew%20Rees">Matthew Rees</a> would continue to serve as the team's captain.
Newport Gwent Dragons entered the season with a new captain. Former <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">Lions</a> player <a href="Lee%20Byrne">Lee Byrne</a> took over from <a href="Andrew%20Coombs">Andrew Coombs</a> on his return from <a href="ASM%20Clermont%20Auvergne">Clermont Auvergne</a> and the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a>. He previously played for rival regions Scarlets and Ospreys.
Like most regions, Ospreys entered the season having lost experienced international players. <a href="Ian%20Evans%20%28rugby%20player%29">Ian Evans</a> and <a href="Richard%20Hibbard">Richard Hibbard</a> were among the players to have departed, with the pair joining <a href="Bristol%20Bears">Bristol</a> and <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a> respectively. The team also lost experienced player <a href="Adam%20Rhys%20Jones">Adam Jones</a>. Jones, who had played in every season for the region since its foundation, stayed within Welsh rugby with a move to Cardiff Blues.
Scarlets entered the season with a new head coach, following <a href="Simon%20Easterby">Simon Easterby</a>'s exit. Easterby left the side to become forwards coach to , working under <a href="Joe%20Schmidt%20%28rugby%20union%29">Joe Schmidt</a>. His replacement was <a href="Wayne%20Pivac">Wayne Pivac</a>, with Pivac joining the region from <a href="ITM%20Cup">ITM Cup</a> side <a href="Auckland%20RFU">Auckland</a>. Scarlets were also without the services of one of the previous season's joint captains <a href="Jonathan%20Davies%20%28rugby%20player%20born%201988%29">Jonathan Davies</a>, who departed to join French side <a href="ASM%20Clermont%20Auvergne">Clermont Auvergne</a>. The side was captained by Welsh international <a href="Ken%20Owens">Ken Owens</a>, with <a href="Scott%20Williams%20%28rugby%20player%29">Scott Williams</a> serving as his deputy in the role.
Fixtures.
All times are local.
Round 20.
Judgement Day.

Leading scorers.
Note: Flags to the left of player names indicate national team as has been defined under <a href="World%20Rugby">World Rugby</a> eligibility rules, or primary nationality for players who have not yet earned international senior caps. Players may hold one or more non-WR nationalities.
End-of-season awards.

2014/2015 Dream Team
